newsitem.title: USA: Omaha mayor seeks convention center complex plan.
newsitem.headline: Omaha mayor seeks convention center complex plan.

text.p: Omaha Mayor Hal Daub will appoint a committee within a few weeks to begin promoting a partly bond financed convention center development that could cost as much as $400 million, a mayoral assistant said Wednesday.

Daub, who narrowly won reelection last week, plans to name a blue ribbon committee to begin marketing a convention center development by mid-June, said Brinker Harding, the mayor's assistant for community growth.
No details have been set, but Daub's development would include a convention center of 250,000 to 300,000 square feet and a multi-purpose arena with seating for 18,000 to 20,000, Harding said.
The mayor wants half private and half public financing that could include issuance of revenue or development bonds and a temporary sales tax increase, Harding said.

Omaha currently has a 6.5 percent sales tax, with 5 percent passed on to the state, Harding said. The city has reached its cap for sales taxes and would need legislative approval to increase the limit.
The arena could serve minor league hockey and basketball tenants as well as major sporting events, concerts and religious programs, Harding said.
